item.title: Offer Contests or Giveaways
item.subtitle: Consumers respond to contests and giveaways. Develop a creative contest or giveaway that gets subscribers reengaged in your brand, while giving them a reason to look forward to your emails. Consider giveaways where smaller prizes are given away daily for, say, one month. Then send emails every day announcing the winner.

item.title: Reward Email Subscribers
item.subtitle: People who are subscribed to your email newsletter did so for a reason: exclusive offers, news, or content that is unique to them. It’s important to deliver on your opt-in promises. Make your recipients feel as though they are part of an exclusive club, and it will give them a reason to stay subscribed to your emails.

item.title: Use Infographics
item.subtitle: Infographics are the current link building craze, and with good reason. Readers love the sound bite approach to consuming information in a world that bombards them with information constantly. Infographics can also be used as a relationship builder, or as a temporary exclusive for a special — and especially influential — online friend.

item.title: Get Detailed Card-Processing Statements
item.subtitle: You want massive detail on your monthly statements whether you understand it or not. You want to see all fees to make the provider expose all rates or fees, to ensure the rates and fees were entered into the processor's system correctly and are as stated on your agreement, and to determine if you have possible operational issues.

item.title: Simple Content Works
item.subtitle: As long as you are providing relevant information that interests the consumer, you can film your product video with a small camera or even a videophone - it doesn’t need to be movie studio quality anymore. It is more important to get the content to the users, to get it in their hands and let them start exploring or being familiar with your content.

item.title: Use Robust Product Descriptions
item.subtitle: As much as we hear that content is king for SEO, many ecommerce websites do not use adequate descriptions of their product, such as what it is, how it works and key points consumers need to know. If you create good content for the consumer, it will also benefit search engine optimization.

item.title: Sort Customer Reviews
item.subtitle: When dealing with a popular product with thousands of reviews, it is helpful to sort them by “Most Helpful First” or “Newest First.” This, coupled with the ability to drill down into specific star ratings, allows for a comprehensive analysis of the product's strength and weaknesses — as described by other customers.

Even the smallest of online retailers are likely to have a Facebook page and a Twitter account, and there are indications that social engagement may improve shopper relations and, possibly, sales. But the process of posting regular updates to social media sites is time consuming. Dlvr.it is a service that can automate and schedule Facebook, LinkedIn, Tumblr, and Twitter posts to better engage potential shoppers. Check them out at Dlvr.it.

item.title: Consider Local Mobile Search
item.subtitle: Local search is when somebody searching for an item is able to find it locally for same day delivery or in-store pickup. As local search becomes more important, more companies are going to have to come online. Consumers are going to drive past a store that has something in stock, to get to a store that they know has something in stock.

item.title: Use More Than One Product Photo
item.subtitle: Because consumers can’t actually touch the products you are selling in your online store, having images depicting multiple angles of your product allows a better understanding of it. This is especially true for products that have many options or features. Consumers want to see what they are buying.

item.title: Start With Good Photographs
item.subtitle: You should always start with a quality product image. Find the right lighting, use a tripod, and make sure your camera is properly focused. Take multiple shots with different lighting and angles - having a larger pool of photos to pull from can help when editing. The more time you take with your initial photos, the better your product images.

item.title: Contribute Positively
item.subtitle: Social media marketing's mission should always be to add real value to the social communities where customers and potential customers are engaged. This means that the content shared should seek to improve the network, not serve as a sort of visual classified ad for the merchant. Spamming communities with unwanted and uninteresting advertisements is a great way to get folks upset.

item.title: Optimize Buttons
item.subtitle: Small changes — like optimizing buttons — can add up to big conversion rate improvements. Many conversion rate improvements use the following common sense principles: Make important buttons stand out with high-contrast colors. Label them as simply as possible. Don’t have too many buttons clustered close together. Following conventions makes customers more comfortable.

item.title: The Voice of Keywords
item.subtitle: To give keywords a voice, simply place them on a website. Cramming all the keywords onto a single glossary page will make each keyword whisper so softly as to be inaudible to search engines. But placing a single keyword at the beginning of the title tag for the page for which it’s most relevant turns the signal for that page up to polite dinner conversation level.

item.title: Tweak Your Default Sort Settings
item.subtitle: The default sort preference for your landing pages can have a big impact on average order value and conversion rates. Increased revenue due to the higher average order value often compensates for the lower conversion rate - conduct conversion tests on your own website to find the optimal recipe.

item.title: Change Advertising Campaigns Fearlessly
item.subtitle: If a campaign that had been performing well enters a slump, gather the information necessary to make a good decision, and be willing to make any changes necessary. If a favorite ad is not making enough conversions to break even, cut it and move on. Rapid response is a good way to get more from advertising.

item.title: Set Pay-Per-Click Expectations
item.subtitle: Pay-per-click ads need to set realistic expectations so that when a user clicks there are no surprises. One popular tactic is to actually include a price in the PPC ad. This way shoppers know how much the product costs, and will presumably click only when they have genuine interest.

item.title: Join a Digital Catalog
item.subtitle: Rather than printing a catalog, merchants can join a group catalog app — which includes products from many different merchants — to get access to a massive stream of new shopping traffic for a fraction of the cost. This brings an important new stream of high quality traffic within the reach of all merchants.

item.title: Set a Reasonable Expiration Date
item.subtitle: Even though promotions should run for a limited period, it's best to give users a few days to see and claim an offer. This also provides time for the offer to spread via word-of-mouth through users' News Feeds. Time the release of your promotion to match your user’s behavior for maximum impact.

item.title: Add Calls to Action to Your Tweets
item.subtitle: Regardless of whether you offer products through an exclusive Twitter account, include calls to action in your tweets. If someone is interested in a particular product, he or she would presumably click the link associated with the tweet — assuming one is provided — but that is not always the case. Sometimes, a little prompting is needed.
